Derek, I also don't believe there has been a great deal of benchmark 
compa=
rison sine the 2003 paper, although Alexandre Devert cites a 
few.  However=
, usually when people attempt benchmarks they do not 
compare their results=
 explicitly with others.

At the same time, as you know, I have changed my =
philosophy somewhat 
since 2003 because I have realized that benchmark comp=
arisons can 
lead to misunderstanding unless they are controlled very caref=
ully.  
One of the problems is the "target-based evolution problem," which =

is one of the inspirations for novelty search.  In short, evolving 
to an =
arbitrary target can lead to misleading intuitions about what 
is possible =
with a particular encoding because of deception.  Often 
a "failed" encodin=
g very well could represent the target if only it 
had been led to it throu=
gh an alternative path through the search 
space.

Also, another problem wi=
th benchmarks is that they may obfuscate 
more fundamental advantages of pa=
rticular approaches because they do 
not focus on general capabilities.  (A=
lthough, of course, if you do 
enough of them, perhaps general capabilities=
 start to be clearer.)  
But that is why I advocated more focus on looking =
for biological-
like regularities in the patterns output by particular enco=
dings, 
rather than looking for a single particular pattern, or even a 
sin=
gle set of patterns.  Like I've said before, evolution never 
produced a wh=
eel but that hardly means DNA is a bad encoding.

Of course benchmarks can =
play a role and I do think more comparisons 
could be done, but we also hav=
e to be cautious about their 
misapplication.

ken



--- In neat@yahoogrou=
ps.com, "David D'Ambrosio" <ddambro84@...> 
wrote:
>
> Hi Derek,
> 
> I'm n=
ot really aware of much, if any benchmarking work that has 
been
> done in =
the field other than some of the papers mentioned in the 
other
> post.  An=
 outsider might think our ultimate goal is to create a 
French
> flag!  I t=
hink it would be great to see such benchmarking of
> artificial embryogeny,=
 as things seem to be about the same as when 
Ken
> wrote his paper: everyo=
ne is just trying stuff with their own 
system,
> without any regard to the=
 other systems out there.
> 
> Ken and I did try to do something like (alth=
ough not as indepth as 
his
> paper suggests) with my 2007 HyperNEAT paper'=
s results.  I built a
> program that let me look at the Hypercube patterns =
and we were 
able to
> learn a lot about HyperNEAT by watching how the patt=
erns changed 
over
> evolution, and were able to isolate modules that contr=
ibuted to 
things
> like symmetry.  We have a forthcoming journal publicati=
on about
> HyperNEAT in general that talks a bit about this.
> 
> David
> 
=
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Derek James" <djames@> wrote:
> >
> > Seein=
g Peter Krcah's stuff (http://ero.matfyz.cz/) at GECCO this 
year
> > got m=
e re-interested in artificial embryogeny. I went back and 
reread
> > Ken's=
 paper "A Taxonomy for Artificial Embryogeny"
> > (http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/=
pub-view.php?PubID=3D121), which is a 
very nice
> > paper. I was specifica=
lly wondering about the suggestions at the 
end
> > of the paper, regarding=
 benchmarks for AE systems, such as:
> > 
> > Evolution of:
> > 
> > --Pure=
 symmetry (e.g. bilateral symmetry)
> > --Specific shapes (e.g. rings, star=
s, and trees)
> > --Specific connectivity patterns (e.g. for neural network=
s)
> > --Simple controllers (e.g. for double pole balancing)
> > 
> > Ken g=
oes on to say:
> > 
> > "Such benchmark comparisons will eventually make it=
 possible to
> > predict the performance
> > of AE systems based on their l=
ocation in the taxonomy. For 
example, one
> > benchmark might be to evolve=
 a five-pointed star. This benchmark 
can
> > be attempted
> > with a syste=
m in which all the dimensions of development are 
fixed
> > except the cell=

> > fate dimension. That dimension can vary from using only 
prepatterning=

> > to using every
> > conceivable form of fate determination, from stocha=
stic
> > self-organization to signaling,
> > migration, and proliferation. =
The results can be measured using
> > several criteria: How
> > fast does t=
he objective shape evolve? How often and how many 
genes
> are reused by
> =
> the solution genome? Is symmetry used, or is each point in the 
star
> > =
specified by a separate
> > section of genetic code=97that is, is there eme=
rgent modularity? 
For
> > every possible
> > setting on the varying dimens=
ion (e.g., cell fate 
determination), data
> > will be available
> > for co=
mparison."
> > 
> > This sounds like a great idea. I'm wondering, though...=
what kind 
of
> > response has this generated? Have there been any follow u=
p 
papers on
> > AE systems that have tried to apply such benchmarks in a 
=
systematic
> > way?
> > 
> > Have these types of benchmarks been systematic=
ally applied to 
the 2D
> > representations evolved using HyperNEAT?
> > 
>=
 > I also noticed rereading Sims 1994 paper that he displays hand-
coded
> =
> examples of recognizable morphologies such as a primate hand, a
> > human=
oid form, and a tree structure. But I'm wondering if and/or 
how
> > easy s=
uch structures arise using his encoding when starting from 
a
> > simple co=
re structure and either using artificial selection or a
> > fitness functio=
n tailored to evoke similar structures.
> >
